Event schedule

Before the event

In order for smooth running of the event, we require that all participants adequately prepare before arriving at the event. We will use Python as the main programming language for demonstration of concepts covered in the summer school. As part of the preparation, software installation and and some light reading outlined below is recommended. Please download and install Anaconda python distribution, version 3.6 and above.

  • Getting started with Jupyter notebooks
  • Introductory SciPy lectures
  • Colab basics
  • Previous DSA events material

All times are in UTC/GMT +2 (SAST — South Africa Standard Time)

Data Visualization

Language: en Complexity: Intermediate

Data Visualization

View presentation

Elaine Nsoesie Assistant Professor, Boston University

DSA Board Member

a Computational Epidemiologist with a passion for applying novel data and methods to global health problems.She leads a team of computational social scientists, public health experts and computer scientists at Boston University's Department of Global Health. She is also a Data Science Fellow, as part of the BU Data Science Initiative at the Hariri Institute for Computing. She was born and raised in Cameroon.

Morine Amutorine Data Associate, UN Global Pulse, Kampala

DSA Board Member

Morine is passionate about analysing, visualising and communicating data. Her work has been dominated by social data including social media data (conducting real-time content analysis and knowledge translation research), public radio (analysing public perceptions on topics that inform the work of the SDGs) and Google search data (to reveal knowledge gaps and detect disparities in health information availability). She particularly enjoys creating data-driven visuals to go with her research findings. She is currently a data associate at UN Global Pulse based in Kampala.

Alice Feng TBD, UNDP

Alice Feng is a data visualization developer based in the Washington, DC area. She is passionate about using design to make data and information more accessible to broader audiences and recently has been exploring ways to bring more diversity, equity, and inclusion into the way we visualize data. Alice is currently making charts and maps for the United Nations Development Programme.
